BUENOS AIRES

Welcome to Argentina

Argentina has many peculiarities that have traveled the world on the lips of its visitors. The outgoing personality of its people, friendly, funny and effusive; the typical gastronomy that goes from asado to mate, through regional dishes and snacks with dulce de leche; traditional dances such as tango, a couple's dance at a rate of 2 by 4 that was born in Buenos Aires in the 19th century and today is spread internationally, or folklore, with the different choreographic forms that it adopts in each region; the passion for soccer and the fanaticism for its main clubs and players, being Boca Juniors and River Plate the most popular, which fill stadiums and cause proliferating displays of fanaticism in each of their matches; the typical games such as Truco, a card game in which luck and the ability to lie or deceive the adversary prevail, or horseback games on the outskirts of the city that reveal the strong influence of Spanish culture and persistence of the old traditions; and, of course, the personality that each region in particular knew how to maintain and strengthen over the years.

The Argentine Republic, with almost 3.8 million km2, is located in the Southern Hemisphere of the American continent. Its 3,800 km long extend from 22º to 55º South latitude. It borders Uruguay, Paraguay, Brazil, Bolivia and Chile on its borders and the Atlantic Ocean to the east. The country is divided touristically into 6 regions and politically into 24 provinces.

Argentina's different regions

Argentina has many different geographical regions that are differentiated from each other by their wheather, flora and fauna, activities, and more. The following is a list of the most famous regions

  • Buenos Aires
  • Patagonia
  • Norte
  • Litoral
  • Cuyo

BUENOS AIRES

Arriving in Buenos Aires is opening the door to discover and fall in love with one of the largest and most cosmopolitan capitals in South America: the Autonomous City of Buenos Aires. With the Obelisk as one of its main icons, the city has multiple options and spaces to explore: modern avenues to beautiful parks and green spaces; buildings and monuments of the national historical heritage (Plaza de Mayo, La Casa Rosada, the Cabildo, the National Congress, the Colón Theater, among others).

But it is well worth going into the heart of Buenos Aires to feel its most passionate tradition: tango. San Telmo, La Boca and Caminito are some of those must-see places. Or visit those that set trends: Palermo, Recoleta and Puerto Madero.

As the main economic and social center of the country, the city is always active. It concentrates all kinds of activities (business, meetings, conventions) and gathers crowds as the venue for major cultural and sporting events.

A few minutes (60 km by highway) you will arrive in La Plata, capital of the province of Buenos Aires and known as "the city of diagonals" for its unique urban layout where the neo-Gothic Cathedral, the Museum of Natural Sciences, among other ideal walks to visit with the family. La Plata is also a place of residence for many young people who come from all over the country attracted by its varied university life.

The Atlantic coast has more than 1,200 kilometers of beach, where thousands of Argentines and tourists rest and enjoy their summer vacations. Mar del Plata is the head city of all the country's spas, as well as being a destination for business tourism. There are the most familiar and traditional beaches such as Necochea, Monte Hermoso, Villa Gesell, Miramar and those of the Partido de la Costa; and others more modern and exclusive like those of Pinamar and Cariló.

Look here at other places that you can visit in the province of Buenos Aires, such as Tandil, Sierra de la Ventana, its rural areas and towns of gaucho tradition such as San Antonio de Areco, Luján, Carlos Keen, Tomás Jofre and Mercedes.

PATAGONIA

The mythical Patagonia treasures incredible natural settings. It is located in the south of the Argentine territory and is conformed by the provinces of La Pampa, Neuquén, Río Negro, La Pampa, Chubut, Santa Cruz and Tierra del Fuego, Antarctica and the South Atlantic Islands.
Among its scenic beauties and great attractions, five World Heritage (UNESCO) sites stand out: Los Glaciares National Park, La Cueva de las Manos, Los Alerces National Park and Valdés Peninsula.
On the one hand, La Cordillera de Los Andes, is imposed from north to south as one of its natural limits and opens up impressive scenarios. Summits of volcanoes with geysers and hot springs; mountains from where huge glaciers, lakes and rivers descend. Charming valleys and mountain villages surrounded by ancient native forests, or extensive steppe fields.
Patagonia also surprises with its biodiversity and its no less incredible wildlife. From maras, rheas, guanacos and the red deer to the condor flying over from the Andes to the mountains by the sea. It is also the habitat of a rich marine world, where numerous species form colonies of sea lions and elephants, Magellan penguins, dolphins, dolphins, and others that arrive seasonally where the Southern Right Whale (Natural Monument) stands out.
Its gastronomy offers you dishes and flavors so well defined that they deserve a mention. Among them, regional meat based on Patagonian lamb, or typical meats of deer, goat, trout and other delicacies that can be perfectly combined with wines of Patagonian origin. Not to be missed are the smoked mincemeats with craft beers and all of them a temptation for chocolates and sweets.

CUYO

The Cuyo Region is located on the Andes Mountains and extends to the south of the Pampas mountains, encompassing the provinces of Mendoza, San Juan and San Luis.

In the mountain range of the Andes, Aconcagua rises (6,959 m.a.s.l.) that attracts adventurers from all over the world in search of reaching the highest summit in America. Other hills such as Tupungato, Mercedario and Cordón del Plata, ideal for mountaineering, climbing and trekking also stand out. And in the winter centers of Mendoza, where you can enjoy the best snow slopes in the region.

By the way, the same Cordillera that invites you to do the Sanmartiniana Route in which the historic liberating expedition of Gral. San Martín was, and ride the crossing of the Andes in Mendoza and San Juan.

Cuyo also stands out for the Wine Route since it concentrates the largest production of wines in the country and a variety of strains (Malbec, Chardonnay, Sauvignon Blanc, Chenin and Riesling, Bonarda, Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, Pinot and Syrah). And you can choose from a variety of wineries, more than a thousand to discover: from small cellars at the foot of the Cordillera, artisanal wineries, boutique wineries or industrial ones. Not to be missed is participating in a grape harvest, taking bike rides or horseback riding among vines and visiting its thematic museums.

In Cuyo you will be able to know more than twenty natural areas, some that are a great attraction for scientific and paleontological tourism. Among its most outstanding points, San Juan has the El Leoncito National Park and the Ischigualasto Provincial Park, the latter included within the World Heritage (UNESCO). And in San Luis, the Sierra de las Quijadas National Park, another must-see in the region.

NORTE

This region of Argentina is conformed by six provinces located in the northwest of the territory: Jujuy, Salta, La Rioja, Catamarca, Santiago del Estero and Tucumán.
It is above all a geography of remarkable contrasts, extraordinary scenic beauty and cultural richness. The aridity of the Puna; the exuberant jungle of the Yungas; Santiago plains almost at sea level, and the more than 6,800 meters of the Andes Mountains. There where the earth shows its geological layers in Talpampaya, exposing ancient secrets, and where each northern landscape frames ancient ruins, Inca period fortresses, colonial chapels, cathedrals and basilicas.
The colors of the Quebrada, the Calchaquí Valleys, the Train to the Clouds, the salt flats, the hot springs, the folklore, the typical dishes and the Torrontés high altitude wine, are just some of the various options that you will be able to enjoy in the northwestern Argentina.
The legacy of native and pre-Columbian civilizations; or its important archaeological and paleontological findings are attractions of great interest to know. The towns of the Quebrada de Humahuaca and the Calchaquíes Valleys, the Inca Trail and the Camino Real, historical places, citadels and pucarás are some of the possibilities to enter the northern culture.
The colors of the hills are expressed in each original piece, ponchos and fabrics that you can find on its artisan routes. Folklore is passed down from generation to generation, and you can hear zambas and chacareras at peñas and festivals. Carnivals, the Pachamama, Inti Raymi and misachicos festivities invite you to celebrate with the local communities in the most intimate of their traditions.

LITORAL

The Litoral region encompasses six provinces in northeastern Argentina, which treasure places that are impressive for their fascinating natural beauty and are a great international tourist attraction. But also, many of them are of utmost importance for the planet and the balanced development of the ecosystem.
Misiones is the scene of tropical jungles, red lands and fabulous waterfalls that make up the Iguazú National Park. Its wealth and exceptional value make this site a natural resource valued as a World Heritage Site by Unesco. Likewise, it attracts international tourist attention due to the exceptional beauty of the Iguazu Falls, considered one of the Seven Wonders of the planet. In the province of Misiones there is also another world fortress, the Jesuit-Guarani Ruins, Historical Cultural Heritage of Humanity.
Corrientes has a formidable wealth in the Esteros del Iberá, which are the second most important wetland in South America. The so-called "Argentine Pantanal" surprises with the biodiversity of flora and fauna, habitat of species such as yacaré overo, the swamp deer, and hundreds of species of birds.
Chaco where El Impenetrable is one of the most impressive treasures of its geography, habitat of species such as the anteater, the tapir, among others, which make this National Park an international ecotourism landmark.
Formosa, is the one of extensive rivers, estuaries, ravines and jungles where you can contemplate diversity of birds and exotic fauna. It is worth visiting El Bañado La Estrella, one of the ideal places to enjoy contact with nature.
Entre Ríos surprises with its thermal complexes, spas and beaches of important rivers such as the Paraná and Uruguay; as well as various ecotourism proposals in the El Palmar National Park; those related to agrotourism, and in summer it attracts with colorful carnivals such as the one in Gualeguaychú.
Santa Fe falls in love with its urban attractions such as active tourism on the banks of the Paraná River. As a complement, the countryside and its ranches are ideal for rural tourism and discovering the Ruta de la Leche. Another prominent place for ecotourism is Jaaukanigás, where the largest RAMSAR site in the country is located and offers a wide range of circuits and options for bird watching, photographic safaris, kayak excursions and more.
